column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0044] In another embodiment, all probes from a universal set may be scored.
#Text=A universal set of probes allows scoring of a relatively small number of probes per sample in a two step process without an undesirable expenditure of time.

#Text=The hybridization process may involve successive probings, in a first step of computing an optimal subset of probes to be hybridized first and, then, on the basis of the obtained results, a second step of determining additional probes to be scored from among those in a universal set.
#Text=Both sets of probes have "negative" probes that confirm the positive probes in the set.
#Text=Further, the sequence that is obtained may then be confirmed in a separate step by hybridizing the sample with a set of "negative" probes identified from the SBH results.
#Text=[0045] In SBH sequence assembly, K-1 oligonucleotides which occur repeatedly in analyzed DNA fragments due to chance or biological reasons may be subject to special consideration.
#Text=If there is no additional information, relatively small fragments of DNA may be fully assembled in as much as every base pair is read several times.

#Text=[0046] In the assembly of relatively longer fragments, ambiguities may arise due to the repeated occurrence in a set of positively-scored probes of a K-1 sequence (i.e., a sequence shorter than the length of the probe).
#Text=This problem does not exist if mutated or similar sequences have to be determined (i.e., the K-1 sequence is not identically repeated).

#Text=Knowledge of one sequence may be used as a template to correctly assemble a sequence known to be similar (e.g. by its presence in a database) by arraying the positive probes for the unknown sequence to display the best fit on the template.
#Text=[0047] The use of an array of sample avoids consecutive scoring of many oligonucleotides on a single sample or on a small set of samples.
#Text=This approach allows the scoring of more probes in parallel by manipulation of only one physical object.
#Text=Subarrays of DNA samples 1000 bp in length may be sequenced in a relatively short period of time.
#Text=If the samples are spotted at 50 subarrays in an array and the array is reprobed 10 times, 500 probes may be scored.
#Text=In screening for the occurrence of a mutation, enough probes may be used to cover each base three times.
#Text=If a mutation is present, several covering probes will be affected.
#Text=The use of information about the identity of negative probes may map the mutation with a two base precision.
#Text=To solve a single base mutation mapped in this way, an additional 15 probes may be employed.
#Text=These probes cover any base combination for two questionable positions (assuming that deletions and insertions are not involved).
#Text=These probes may be scored in one cycle on 50 subarrays which contain a given sample.

#Text=In the implementation of a multiple label color scheme (i.e., multiplexing), two to six probes, each having a different label such as a different fluorescent dye, may be used as a pool, thereby reducing the number of hybridization cycles and shortening the sequencing process.
#Text=[0048] In more complicated cases, there may be two close mutations or insertions.
#Text=They may be handled with more probes.
#Text=For example, a three base insertion may be solved with 64 probes.
#Text=The most complicated cases may be approached by several steps of hybridization, and the selecting of a new set of probes on the basis of results of previous hybridizations.
